L. As at
e writing of my
last,
e towne of Gertrudenbergh continueth besieged.
The first attempt that they w
t
out gave against it, was
on
e water side w
t
fire workes, and other artificiall
engines, wherew
t
they had filled a shippe, supposing
by it to have cast downe a great part of
e walle,
and to have sett many houses a fire. But it pro-
ved in triall a weake devise, scorned at by suche as
stoode uppon
e walles, and that litle harme
at it did
fell uppon themselves. There folowed uppon it
a long batterie, whiche continued divers daies, and
some nightes, untill
e breache was esteemed reaso-
nable: and then sundrie of
e chiefest in place, as
e
Count of Holmes
,
Count Philip
,
Mareshall Villiers
,
and others gave
e assault w
t
a great furie, comming
to it w
t
flatte bottom boates. But they were forced
to retire immediatly, finding
e resistance of the
garrison very resolut and desperat, and
e meanes
to assault out of their boates, full of comber and
disadvantage. The Mareshall Villers was shotte
into
e knee, but like to recover it quickly. The
two Viceadmirals of
Holland
and
Zeland
were shotte into
e armes: w
ch
it is thought they will
be forced to cutte of. A brother of
Mons
r
Brede-
rode
was slaine, and divers captaines besides, of
good account and service, partly slaine, and partly
hurt: as also a great part of
Count Maurice
gard
and of
e c
o
mon souldiers. Uppon
e newes of
this repulse, this
Councell of state
made request by
their letters sent to
e camp, to
e states deputies
there,
at they would use my presence and assistance
for effecting some accord: Wherto they never made
answear,
since,
e
nor since
e siege beganne never writ
hither to any of these assemblies for any advise. Ne-
vertheles for a further discharge of my duty in this place
and for that it was a c
o
mon speeche of
e people,
at

e ennemie
I writte a letter to S
r
John whereby I requested him to
fol.1v
be advertised from him, if any likelyhoode were left,
among those in
e towne,
at I might be an in-
strument of a good composition. I required him
further in her
Ma
ties
name, to take a speciall
care, that
e towne might not falle into
e ennemies
possession. This letter I sent open to
e camp,
desiring it might be sent, or suppressed, as the
Count and
e rest shold finde most behoofull.
Howebeit
ei sent it immediatly, and w
t
muche
a doe it was receaved, and
e answear given
not by S
r
John but by
e rest, That they would
have no further dealing w
t
her Ma
tie
or any of her
ministers, for
at my
L. Willughbies
proceedinges
were discovered sufficiently. The cause of w
ch
answear proceeded hereof. The Count not wil-
ling to come againe to
e assault, thought by
other practises, to make a division among those of
e garrison, and theruppon sent a certaine Act
unto them, whiche my L. Willughby long since
gave unto
e Count, to assure him of his good
meaning for
e deliverie of
e towne into his
handes. The sighte of that Act made a soddaine
alteration among them. For wheras before they
pretended still to hold for her Ma
tie
they began
then to disclame, and to use railing speeches
against my L. and
e Inglishe nation, that
went about in
at order to betray them. And
howe they intreated S
r
John uppon it I knowe
not yet certainly: but it is bruited abroade,
that
ei have him in custody. My letter comming
thither, uppon
e delivery of this Act, tooke no other
effect: and since continually, they have answea-
red
e ennemies fires, and sent unto them three
out of their garrison, to Capitulat about yelding
up
e towne: w
t
whome it is also said, that
e
Duke himself being come to
Breda
hath had
c
o
ference, and hath already skirmished w
t
e Count.
Heeruppon both he and
e rest there very muche
fol.2r
perplexed, sent yesterday to
e Councell hither,
requesting
at I would come in person, and make
triall, if better successe would come of it. I made
answear, that if
at course had bin taken at first,
when her Ma
ties
name was used and respected in
e
towne, I douted not, but they might have bin brought
to some tolerable conditions. But nowe,
e ennemie
being come to
e walles, it seemed a desperat case:
nevertheles I referred my service to
e Councels
disposition, req
e
sting them to c
o
ferre many mens
advertisments together, touching
e state of
e towne,
and then to resolve, as they should thinke best,
about my imploiment: wherein they bestowed some
time presently, and found it all too [late], expecting
letters every houre of
e ennemies entrie, and
e re-
trait of o
r
men. Not to troble yo
r
L. w
t
the
relation of all particular accidents, uppon
e occa-
sion of this enterprise, and
e unhappy successe, there
is nothing heere but feare, and troble, and confu-
sion, aswell among
e better sort, as
e common
people, some fewe crieng out against S
r
John Wing-
fild and
e Inglish nation, but
e farre greater
part against
e autors of
e action: whiche I
can not yet learne, to have bin any other then
e
Count,
barnevelt
and Villiers: but Barnevelt
in speciall, whose greedy desire of revenge against
those of
e towne, and my L. Willughby hath
wrought this effect. Moreover their delivery
of my L. Willughbies Act is generally condem-
ned as a dishonorable dealing towardes my L.
and very inconsiderat in respect of themselves.
For by it they excluded themselves from all
kind of hope of any good composition. All
their allegations in excuse of this Exploit are very
frivolous and fained. They say that those of
e
towne have bin practising a long time w
t
e ennemy
That
e losse of
e towne is of no suche importance,
as men commonly give out, That
e inconvenience
whiche would have ensued in other garrisons, if
fol.2v
e insolence of those of Gertrudenbergh should
have bin wincked at, must needes have done them greater
harme: w
t
other like shiftes and devises both untrue,
and of no moment. In effect
e state of these
Provinces, is weaker at this present, then it hath
bin these many yeres, and unles by her Ma
ties
extraordinary assistance and counsell it be pre-
sently holpen, there is like apparance,
at they can
hold it out long. The losse of this towne of
Gertrudenbergh,
e absence of her Ma
ties
Lieutenant,
the w
t
drawing of forces, and
e imperfection of
this government, are great opportunities to drawe
e ennemie onward, and to dismay
e people.
In w
ch
respect I doe expect nothing more, then
to knowe her Ma
ties
intention:
e want whereof,
I must needes c
o
fesse to yo
r
L. doth somwhat

r

lation of these occurrences to her Hig
nes
